in 2015 if you were in Minnesota going

these are just some of the signs that

the reason Walter Palmer a dentist

at his dental practice Walter Palmer has
been publicly shamed public shaming is
an old phenomenon given new life by

bringing back everything but the stalks
and literal tomatoes the term shaming is
an understatement
too since these often have tangible

from the public and sometimes these
effects can feel deserved but there are

from the absolutely heinous to

Twitter goes on and on until someone is
fired or canceled your reputation can be
destroyed in an instant so I wanted to
ask why has public shaming become so
popular and is it making the world a
better place or is it more harm than
good for a great deal of human history
people lived in small communities where
public punishment and shaming was common
if you are caught stealing you might get
ten lashings at the center of town and
these public punishments helped
reinforce social norms both for the
criminal
and the onlookers the criminal was
shamed in front of a crowd that knew him
and the onlooking community would think
I never want that to happen to me but
despite this dual benefit to society
this public justice slowly fell out of
fashion around the early 20th century a
common explanation for this is that as
people move to densely populated cities
shaming loses its stink because if
you're ever seriously shamed you can
just disappear into another crowd within
your city the threat of public shaming
just isn't as motivating but this
landscape completely changed with the
rise of the internet suddenly we're all
placed back in the same small village
again because our digital footprint
follows us everywhere New York or New
Hampshire you're always searchable and
your internet skin is are a click away
now of course some things have changed
you won't literally be whipped during
your shaming we've done away with
corporal punishment so that's good but
in some ways the way we publicly shame
is more brutal than our ancestors
because our new internet mobs cannot
forgive consider that in the past the
public mob might gather in the street
for an hour the wit man whipped ten
times and it was over the criminal had
literally taken their licks and then the
person could be reintegrated back into
society but today the public mob gathers
on Twitter's for days for months we all
take a crack with no one counting
without even a number to count towards
there is no leader to an outraged
collective which means nobody can say
when it's over because no one of us
speaks for all of us our forgiveness is
fragmented so as long as someone is
willing to continue the public shaming
it will continue but it doesn't end
there modern shavings are also brutal
because they are impersonal just words
on a screen we don't know the person
we're trashing online whereas before you

maybe he was your neighbor caught in

you can't ignore what you're doing to

is what it was like to be one of the

power is a slippery thing in a mob what

the person you're shaming has lost their

and everything they've worked for you're
not punching up anymore
you're kicking a guy while he's down
secondly when there's no due process
mistakes are made like when the Internet
mob went after Sunil Tripathi and his

so instead of being heroes and catching

public shaming in some ways represents
the best and worst of us
it represents our collective desire for

short-sighted and often unforgiving mob
mentality continuing a culture of public
